metadata.Name: BoolQ
metadata.Description: A question answering dataset for yes/no questions. Each example consists of a naturally occurring question, a passage from Wikipedia, and a boolean (yes/no) answer. The questions were sourced from anonymized, aggregated Google search queries.
metadata.Paper Title: BoolQ: Exploring the Surprising Difficulty of Natural Yes/No Questions
metadata.Venue Title: Proceedings of the 2019 Conference of the North American Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics: Human Language Technologies, Volume 1 (Long and Short Papers)
metadata.Venue Name: Conference of the North American Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics: Human Language Technologies
metadata.Abstract: Question answering is a major focus of NLP research. However, existing datasets are either small in scale or created using artificial processes such as crowdsourcing or dependency parsing. In this paper, we present a new question answering dataset, BOOLQ, containing 15,942 examples. These are naturally occurring questions, generated in an unconstrained setting. Each example is a triplet of (question, passage, answer), with the passage sourced from a Wikipedia article. We explore the surprising difficulty of this new dataset, as BERT-based models only achieve around 80% accuracy, which is well below human performance (94%). We also show that transfer learning from other QA datasets does not improve performance. Finally, we perform a detailed linguistic analysis of our dataset and show that it contains a rich variety of challenging phenomena that are not well-represented in existing datasets.
